iati-activity.title: Support for Indoor Residual Spraying in Malaria Endemic Areas in Kenya
iati-activity.description: To protect over 3.5 million people from malaria by conducting indoor insecticide spraying in high malaria transmission zones in Kenya. This will reduce deaths from malaria thus contributing to achievement of the Millennium Development Goals on reduced child mortality and reduced incidence of major diseases by 2015

iati-activity.title: Arid Lands Support Programme
iati-activity.description: To improve the coping strategies for over 500,000 of the poorest people in Northern Kenya (Turkana, Wajir, Mandera and Marsabit counties) to help them to adapt to climate change and improve their livelihoods. The programme will also provide opportunities to support the poorest during drought, provide benefits for livestock insurance, increase average real value of assets owned by households, and will allow 64,000 beneficiaries to become less poor relative to non-beneficiaries in the four counties.

contact-info.mailing-address: Public Enquiry Point, Abercrombie House, Eaglesham Road, East Kilbride, Glasgow G75 8EA

iati-activity.related-activity: Index Based Livestock Insurance
To provide a fund designed to improve rapid disaster response and reduce risks associated with shocks such as droughts
The BOMA Project: Reducing Vulnerability and Strengthening Climate Resilience in Marsabit County, Kenya
Community Resilience Initiatives
To provide expertise to support institutional development for coordination, arid lands policy development, and monitoring and evaluation of results.
Oxfam: Strengthening Community Resilience in Wajir County, Kenya
Trocaire: Strengthening Community Resilience in Turkana County, Kenya
Save the Children: Building Resilience in the Arid Lands in Mandera County, Kenya

iati-activity.description: To improve the lives of at least 10,000 adolescent girls in Kenya between the age of 10 and 14, by improving their access to health, education, economic assets and protection from violence. iati-activity.title: Affordable appliances for poor people in developing countries
iati-activity.description: This initiative, which DFID is co-funding with the Shell Foundation, will support research into reducing the cost and increasing the application of mobile-to-mobile technology that both reduce the costs and increase the availability of products and services (for example solar lanterns and other household appliances) to poor people. It will do this by testing ways of enabling poor people to pay for such appliances in small increments as they use them, thereby both reducing the initial purchase costs which are often prohibitive for the poor, and by demonstrating the viability of alternative, lower cost business/retail models to the enterprise sector. The research will also potentially help make available to poor people cleaner, more effective/efficient technologies at an affordable price. Initial products to be tested will be focused on energy access technologies (such as solar home systems), but results will be relevant for other products in other sectors.

contact-info.mailing-address: Public Enquiry Point, Abercrombie House, Eaglesham Road, East Kilbride, Glasgow G75 8EA

This will contribute to increased exports and regional trade in East Africa benefitting the regional population.

iati-activity.title: Strengthening Adaptation and Resilience to Climate Change in Kenya Plus (StARCK+)
iati-activity.description: To achieve transformational change by helping Kenya to scale up private sector innovation and investment in low carbon and adaptation products, services and assets (e.g. clean energy, sustainable agriculture, water management, weather forecasting). Enabling this change will require targeted support to critical aspects of climate change governance, and stimulation of civil society demand. This contributes to the UK Governmentâs International Climate Fund (ICF) commitments and will benefit 828,000 people able to cope with the effects of climate change and 17,600 people with improved access to clean energy.
